table-wrap.anchoringText: Although the MMP with tuned EOS is still not exactly matched with the lab test result (2570 psi), it deviates to the ‘conservative’ side. In the near miscible region (i.e. in the region below the calculated MMP), simulation results will be conservative, which bodes well for our predictions. The impact of EOS tuning on the MMP of HC gas was limited because only parameters related to the CO2 component were tuned and the CO2 composition in HC gas is only 3%as shown in Table 1.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Composition of Miscible Injectants

table-wrap.anchoringText: The producer was controlled to sustain the target oil rate and injectors were controlled to maintain the average reservoir pressure at 4200 psi which is higher than the MMP of CO2 and HC gas. The WAG injection started after 45 years and 72 years water injection for Heterogeneous and Homogeneous model, respectively, in order to be matured for the tertiary mode WAG injection. The simulation models are shown in Fig. 9 and Table 2 summarizes the model characteristics.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Model Characteristics

table-wrap.anchoringText: In order to resolve the disadvantage of these cases, the concept of ‘Tapered’ WAG was utilized (Khan et al. 2016). In the Tapered WAG, the durations of gas injection vary over time with longer gas injection cycles occurring earlier while shorter gas cycles occur later (Table 3 and Fig. 12). The goal of using a Tapered WAG process is to accelerate the response time and optimize gas utilization without adversely impacting oil recovery. Fig. 13 and Fig. 14 show the comparison of Tapered CO2 WAG with constant CO2 WAG (4:1) and the effects on recovery factor and GOR for Heterogeneous and Homogeneous model, respectively.
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: Design of Tapered WAG Injection Cycles

formatted-caption.caption-text: Design of Tapered WAG Injection Cycles
